contextId.information: Stirring the spirit is a metonym for making someone want to act. "Yahweh ... made Cyrus want to act" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The voice is a metonym for the message the voice speaks, and the kingdom is a metonym for the people whom a king rules. AT: "Cyrus sent a message to everyone over whom he ruled" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Cyrus' voice went out over his entire kingdom

contextId.information: Stirring the spirit is a metonym for making someone want to act. Similar words appear in [[:en:bible:notes:ezr:01:01|1:1]]. AT: "everyone whom God had made want to go" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: everyone whose spirit God stirred to go

contextId.information: This refers to the first temple that Solomon built, the house of God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Possible meanings are that this refers to 1) the writers being loyal to the king (UDB) or 2) the king giving the writers special honors. AT: "we are loyal to you" or "you have honored us by making us your officials" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: we have eaten the palace salt

contextId.information: This can be translated in active form, in which case you will need to make explicit who destroyed the city. AT: "the Babylonians destroyed the city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

The hand is a metonym for power or control. Also, "Nebuchadnezzar" represents his army. AT: "allowed Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, and his army to destroy this house and to take the people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: he gave them into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, who destroyed this house and took the people

contextId.information: Lifting the hand represents trying or daring to do something. AT: "who tries to change ... or to destroy"  or "who dares to change ... or to destroy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: who lifts a hand to change ... or to destroy

contextId.information: Turning the king's heart represents making him think differently about the work of the temple. AT: "changed the attitude of Assyria's king" or "made Assyria's king willing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: turned the heart of Assyria's king

contextId.information: The "hand" of Yahweh represents Yahweh's blessing or help. AT: "the blessing of Yahweh was with Ezra" or "Yahweh was blessing Ezra" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the hand of Yahweh was with him

contextId.information: God's "good hand" represents his kindness in providing for them. AT: "Because God was kind to us, they sent us a man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: So they sent us by our God's good hand a man

contextId.information: God's might and wrath being on people is a metonym for him punishing people. Forgetting God is a metaphor for refusing to serve him. AT: "but he punishes all who refuse to serve him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: but his might and wrath are on all who forget him

contextId.information: The hand of God being on people is a metonym for God helping people. AT: "God was helping us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The hand of our God was on us

contextId.information: The hand represents what those people might do. It specifically refers to the enemy attacking the group that was traveling. AT: "he protected us from the attack of the enemy and the ones who wished to ambush us along the road" or "He kept the enemy from attacking us and he kept robbers from ambushing us along the road" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: he protected us from the hand of the enemy and the ones ... road

contextId.information: Here "the hand of Meremoth" represents Meremoth's care of the silver, gold, and objects. The men weighed those things and gave them to Meremoth to take care of them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the silver, gold, and objects were weighed out ... into the hand of Meremoth

contextId.information: The face is a metonym for the shame that the person feels and that others who see that person's face know he feels. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
